newsitem.title: HONG KONG: PRESS DIGEST - HK newspaper headlines - Oct 4.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - HK newspaper headlines - Oct 4.

text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Hong Kong press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

-- MING PAO DAILY NEWS -- Three nominees to join the Selection Committee that will choose Hong Kong's future leaders were barred because they would not support the Provisional Legislature that is to replace the current elected council.

-- Beijing-funded TA KUNG PAO -- Reacting to the last policy address of Governor Chris Patten, deputy-director Zhang Junsheng of the New China News Agency Hong Kong branch said China did not want to argue with Patten and asked him to stop making trouble.
-- China plans major reforms of its science and technology structure and will invite tenders for planned projects.
-- HONG KONG ECONOMIC JOURNAL -- Peter Woo, who is running for the post of Hong Kong's future Chief Executive, said he had never lobbied Beijing for his own benefit.

-- HONG KONG ECONOMIC TIMES -- Giordano International will set up a joint venture with two well-known state enterprises in China, with branches in Beijing and Shanghai. The company said the deal proved that its China business had normalised.
-- English-language SOUTH CHINA MORNING POST -- Debt-ridden Shanghai Hai Xing Shipping Co will reduce interest expenses by 22 million yuan this year, after refinancing its debt burden.
-- Analysts and insurance officials called on China to relax its ban on insurance companies investing in shares to help stabilise the country's immature stock markets.
-- English-language HONGKONG STANDARD -- The flotation of mobile telecommunications provider SmarTone aimed at raising between US$216 million and US$266 million.
-- Chinese medicine maker Sanjiu Group hoped to raise at least 700 million yuan by listing shares in a Shenzhen joint venture on the Hong Kong stock exchange.

-- ORIENTAL DAILY NEWS -- The leader of the Hong Kong organization Yellow Bird which helped many Chinese dissidents escape overseas following the 1989 Tiananmen crackdown was wounded in a knife attack in the Mong Kok district.
